description.text: This Thing lets you convert a piece of bungee cord into a general purpose adjustable, secure, yet easily undoable elastic fastener. They are often used to attach a bicycle to a car bike rack, but can be used in plenty of other situations, such as tying up intruders until the police arrive. Source for this lives at https://cubehero.com/physibles/Lenbok/Bungee_Cord_Connector

Get yourself some good quality elastic cord.
The STL here is designed for 5mm diameter elastic cord. If you have a different diameter cord, either scale the STL or jump into the SCAD and adjust accordingly.
Print out the connector.
In fact, print out several.
Cut your elastic cord to the desired length (about 70cm is good). Probably you want to melt the ends to prevent fraying.
Poke one end through the "short" side of the connector from the outside, tie a knot as close to the end as possible, and pull the cord back, so the knot nestles nicely in the connector.
Repeat for as many cords as you want.
Now, to use it, you wrap the cord around Your Thing (not this Thing), poke the free end of the cord through the connector and pull it such that it tightens. See the pictures if you still don't get it.
Take a photo and hit the "I made one" button.
You are done.

description.text:
A remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:242898 designed to work with JAWong's amazing Catan tiles http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26979
I've also designed some seaside tiles with matching bases http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1108755 I couldn't find any cylindrical magnets polarised correctly.
Spherical magnets are cheap, easily available and are able to rotate achieving the same effect.
One a side will work, they're not particularly strong so I used two a side.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

25%

Notes: Best printed with the holes down to achieve a good gluing surface.

I sourced the magnets here http://www.aliexpress.com/item/New-216-Pcs-3mm-Sphere-Ball-Neodymium-Rare-Earth-Super-Magnets-N35-Free-Shipping/32269492974.html?spm=2114.01020208.3.12.KTYf64&ws_ab_test=searchweb201556_3_71_72_73_74_75,searchweb201644_5,searchweb201560_9 I painted the bases with Acetone and pressed them onto the Catan tiles.
Alternatively you can use glue if you've printed with PLA.
Make sure not to get any acetone/glue down the holes, the magnets need to rotate! If some are stuck after assembly I used a very strong magnet to free them.
Tap the location of the internal magnet with a larger magnet. Try different orientations.

description.text:
My first test in captive 3D printing.  
Australian currency is water proof and rip proof, but unfortunately it's not always accepted in smaller FOREXs. US dollars are accepted everywhere but made out of paper. This is my solution for carrying an emergency money supply when travelling. Protected and discreet.

Make sure that your infill is high enough to ensure that your walls don't wind up as seperate laminations. Use the keyring hole as an indicator of the end of print, then do the following;
  • pause
  • using Pronterface move your print head out of the way, remember how far you've moved it
  • carefully insert the money
  • move the print head back to precisely where it was
  • resume print

These models were created for a 7th grade cross-curricular "culture fair." See the PDF file for a full description of the project. As part of the project the kids had to make  stand-up maps of their chosen country and then embellish it with the country name or something representative of the country.
The Mexico model was my example, the other models were created by the students using Tinkercad.
NGSS

These models were created for a 7th grade cross-curricular "culture fair." See the PDF file for a full description of the project. As part of the project the kids had to make  stand-up maps of their chosen country and then embellish it with the country name or something representative of the country.

• Use the Internet to find a map of their country
  • If they find a monochrome map it can be converted into SVG using a free online image converter. Searching with terms like "clip art," "outline," "silhouette," and "black and white" will improve your chances of finding a suitable map
  • If the map is not monochrome it can be inserted into a Google Drawing. Then use the line tools to trace the outline. After deleting the original map image the tracing can be downloaded as an SVG file.
  • Import the map SVG file in Tinkercad, make the height (z direction) at least 10 mm
  • Add a rectangular base to the map so that it will stand up when printed
  • If the map is in several pieces (the islands of Japan, for example) connect the pieces to each other and the base with rectangular beams
  • Embellish the map by using the Text Generator or adding shapes that are symbolic or have cultural significance. Images can be imported using the same method as was used for the map
  • Double check that all parts are connected, and the height (z direction) is 10 mm or greater
  • Print your model

description.header: Project: Stand Up Maps of Countries
description.text:
Objective Design a stand up map of a country Audience This was a 7th grade project, but could work for grades 4 - 10 Preparation This project was part of a "culture" fair that combined social studies, art, home economics (cooking), and literature. The students had limited experience with Tinkercad.com Steps
  • Use the Internet to find a map of their country
  • If they find a monochrome map it can be converted into SVG using a free online image converter. Searching with terms like "clip art," "outline," "silhouette," and "black and white" will improve your chances of finding a suitable map
  • If the map is not monochrome it can be inserted into a Google Drawing. Then use the line tools to trace the outline. After deleting the original map image the tracing can be downloaded as an SVG file.
  • Import the map SVG file in Tinkercad, make the height (z direction) at least 10 mm
  • Add a rectangular base to the map so that it will stand up when printed
  • If the map is in several pieces (the islands of Japan, for example) connect the pieces to each other and the base with rectangular beams
  • Embellish the map by using the Text Generator or adding shapes that are symbolic or have cultural significance. Images can be imported using the same method as was used for the map
  • Double check that all parts are connected, and the height (z direction) is 10 mm or greater
  • Print your model
    • Results Students were able to design and print a 3D model of their country.

This is a simple pop-filter for your microphone. This is the "thing" you put between the mic and your mouth. It's used for making the chaotic air flow from your mouth into a linear flow which will hit the membrane of the mic more gently which will result in better sound quality of the audio.
I've printed mine with natural color PLA, 50% infill and 0.3mm layer height. Unfortunately for me - I didn't made the options of the G-code as they should be and this result that I couldn't put the nuts in their traps. Still working though...I just had to use longer screws. So be carefull about that!
The screws are 2 pcs x M3x14 with nylon nuts (for the cable clamp, explained below) and 1 pcs x M3x20 with normal nut (M3x25 with nylon nut if you couldn't put the normal nut into it's nut-trap). As a membrane I've cutted an old sock and put it between the two circles. You'll have great results with women's sock (in 2 layers) cutted to shape, as well. Just make sure you stretch the sock as much as possible.
To hold the pop-filter to your mic's frame - use a plumbing clamp or a zip-tie (or even a duct-tape) and a large AWG cable or some sort of a stick. The 3D printed part have a clamp to hold the cable/stick to the pop-filter. Update: Based on the things I noticed due my build, I have made some changes to the 3D model of the pop-filter. It's called "PopFilter-110mm-Improved" and it has larger screw holes, larger nut-traps, smaller inner diameter of the outer ring (the clamping circle) to make the things a little bit tighter and also made an oval hole for the screw when the M3 nut-trap is (to make the assembly a little bit easier). The real pictures you see here are from the original basic version (PopFilter.stl), both are working. Cheers! Pictures update #2: As you can see, I've mounted my pop-filter with a piece of a clothes hanger (the metallic wire one) to the filter on one side and with big zip-ties to the frame of my microphone tripod. :)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

50%

title: Reprap32 -- 32Bit Reprap control based on AVR32

description.text:
This is a Reprap 32bit control board based upon AVR32 (AT32UC3B0256) CPU.
It is a functional replacement for the Gen4 Aruduino mega and it's motherboard. The code has been ported to AVR32 GCC from Makerbot G3 branch (the V2 code), Status: As of OCT 8th, 2011
The atmel CDC driver for USB is now running on the hardware with terminal emulators. The next step is to port it into tha main REPRAP32 application. I will probably try a USB branch on the main git repository. I have not yet published a branch and need to learn how to do it correctly. I have some bare stepstick PCBs in hand now. So I can build a full stepstick based prusia with USB reprap32 for my daughter at college. I checked the loading of the 64us stepper timer interrupt to see how much cpu time the steppers are using. I found 22% nominal and 36% worst case. This leaves 53 DMips of cpu still available. I was able to drive the Gen3 stepper drivers on my Prusa with no issues. Just a cable slide from 10 pin to 6 pin IDC. I did not even change any settings in ReplicatorG!!! it just works. Most of my issues were related to pin assignments and not having end stops
Properly terminated. They are now disconnected in the software build. check out http://sites.google.com/site/reprap32

I will push the new version to Github after Labor day, 
github link www.github.com/daveland/reprap32
I still need to make a part list (BOM) and some other documentation.
Contributors to this project are Welcome!!!  If you have something to add let me know.  I work way too slowly so help is always appreciated.

comments.text: Reprap32 Now Prints!!!  I made the first pair of test cubes this evening.  I found that I could use the Gen3 stepper drivers with just a cable offset.  No changes to ReplicatorG were required.  It printed really well.  Now on to unfinished things,  EEPROM , config Settings, and Stress testing.
comments.author: davelandia

comments.text: Davelandia - I just happened to stumble upon this - I've actually got the AT32UC3C1512C that I'm implementing for a 32 bit controller. This puppy has on board CAN, Ethernet, USB 2.0 as well as a FPU. My purpose is to expand the featureset available on board but also to implement new GCode maneuvers such as Arc that are computationally intensive and require a significant amount of precision. This will allow for true curves as opposed to tangental linear movements of the print head. What's more is that I also want to get this beast connected online by ethernet.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Hi.. I was looking at the UC3C series, But could not find any stock in Febuary when I began the design.  But I was hoping to port to it  once the chips came out.
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: Once I get it running, we could combine forces to port to the UC3C and layout a new board.  This layout was tight for 2 layers, and I think the next would need to be 4 layer.
comments.author: davelandia

comments.text: What is the benefits of going 32bit?
comments.author: smartroad

comments.text: Speed mainly.  as you move to shorter line segments, acceleration, and constant velocity around corners, you require more calculation power.  32bit cpus are now capable of doing 32 /64 bit math in single instructions.  This allows more moves per second.
comments.author: smartroad

comments.text: Thanks for the explanation. I have thought about using an Arm based processor that would be powerful enough to also skein as well for a all in one solution. But my limit is the Arduino unfortunately :(
comments.author: davelandia

comments.text: The AVR32 is close to the ARM cortex M3 in CPU computing power.  Most of these cpu's are similar since the MFGRS all compete with each other. It's all about peripherals and chip  cost.
comments.author: smartroad

comments.text: Seems that Arduino are now bringing out an  ARM based board as well. Seems to be based on the mega, I wonder how compatible it would be to the exsisting firmware? The thing I would really like is an LCD controller so I can go totally stand alone with my Huxley rather then having to run my PC to monitor it.
comments.author: davelandia

comments.text: I agree that the world is awash with processor options. Multiple ARM vendors/AVR32/ and the new flavors of old avr.  All of these require the firmware to be ported and it is not just a simple re-compile.  The chips have different peripherals so there is no single code base that can run on them all.  Arduino looks to be on track to get there someday.

comments.text: Nice to see the movement to 32 bits. If this also means that silly serial bottleneck is eliminated then it is all for the better.

title: Customizable Flush Mount Quick Change Platen Brackets

description.text: Occasionally my nozzle or fan duct will crash into one of the binder clips securing down my platen. These customizable flush mount brackets hold the platen down while staying out of the way. Also it's much quicker installing and removing the platen with these brackets; two eccentric retainers just need to be rotated out of the way allowing the platen to easily lift out. While using the customizer, you may select each individual part to preview using the "Part" drop down menu which is available in all tabs. To have a zoomed in view of an individual part go to the [Build plate] tab and set the "Show Build Plate" dropdown to "No". You may also tweak the display of the build plate here in accordance with your own printer platform. Set "bed_y_mount_height" equal to the nominal center to center distance of the bed mounting holes in the y-axis. The default of 209mm works for the MK2 (http://reprap.org/wiki/PCB_Heatbed) Measure the thickness of your build platen and set "platen_thick" equal to this value. The default value of 2.4mm works for a 3/32" plate. The brackets are naturally larger than your platen so they'll need to be oriented diagonally when printing in order to fit. To assemble, orient the long edges of the brackets parallel to the Y-axis and arrange the short edges (the stops) kitty-corner each other. Put an eccentric retainer over each mount slot and affix to the bed as usual. Preferably use button cap screws to minimize the Z protrusion. If the plastic eccentrics stops are too flimsy to secure your platen you can try printing them thicker by adjusting the "eccentric_thick" value. Alternatively, reinforcing the eccentrics stops with fender washers works well. If any of the corners are still not securely held in place, just build up that corner of the platen with several layers of tape. The brackets should be snug against the platen on all four sides. The eccentric retainers will hold the platen down. To quickly remove the platen turn the front two eccentrics to release the platen then lift up and slide it out.

description.text: A small program to read Digital Elevation Model HGT files (Space Shuttle Radar Tomography) or Image files and convert them to STLs

*v0.3.0.0 Added support for importing images. These are converted to greyscale and can then be converted to STLs
  • Added a 'base' option that can be trimmed to the object / landmass or cover the full extend of the area.
  • Redesigned the interface.
    v 0.2.0.0 Rounding error caused some latitudes to generate errors. Fixed in this version.
    v 0.1.1 Improved error checking - errors can send an error report to me if you choose.
    • HTG files can be downloaded from http://www.viewfinderpanoramas.org/dem3.html. on the map (http://www.viewfinderpanoramas.org/Coverage%20map%20viewfinderpanoramas_org3.htm) select an area to download the zipped tiles for that area. Unzip and select a tile in HGT2STL.exe. A greyscale image of the tile is shown. Water (or actually height = 0) is blue. Draw over an area to export just a portion of the map, set 'Desample' to reduce the resolution of the map. Select 'Save as ASCII STL' to output a map. The program is - and will only ever be - Windows only! Sorry, but that is what I know and use. (Delphi XE3 source is available) Generated STLs are ASCII format. I may add binary in the future - time and interest permitting.... Max resolution for these maps is about 1 facet = 90m. Higher res DEMs are available - for a price! This porgram can only read the HGT format though. Program is quick & dirty - almost NO error checking! PBill4.zip & La Palma are zipped ASCII STLs of the maps shown in the screenshots.

Hi There
This is great - many thanks for your generosity in sharing your app.
I have been playing around with this, and have noticed that the STLs being generated have features that appear to be around ten times higher than they should be (this is only a visual approximation). What am I doing wrong / missing?
(I rescale the STL to a more reasonable height ration)
I noticed also that if an entire tile geo-tile is processed, then the bottom side faces do not match the topography, and leave openings and overlaps.
comments.author: burroujh

comments.text:
Thanks for the comments. I must confess I have not done anything with the program since I posted it - it was just a fun project at the time...
It's true the vertical scaling is far from accurate in the default setting. It was done more for effect and fun than topographical accuracy and academics. You can set it to a much smaller value though to be more accurate.
I'm not sure what you mean by the 'bottom side faces'. I know I had some problems initially with getting the sides and bottom to make solid faces but I thought that was sorted by the time I posted it. It may be that the geo-tile you are using has some odd combination of contours that is throwing stuff off. If you could let me know which tile it is I can try it out.
comments.author: burroujh

comments.text:
Hi there
Thanks for that. Do you know what a more accurate setting should be ?
All the tiles I've looked at seem to have problems with the bottom faces. The side faces are perfect.
For example, I have downloaded SI34 (Southern Cape - RSA): S33E018 (You can choose any tile in this range, I suspect). The faces that make up the southern edge do not make a closed seam in relation to the topography (The east faces do close properly)
Another question: Can the generated image be saved to a large high def image file?

comments.text:
quick note on my work flow from a few sources
Get a dem file
Open in microdem.exe
Show as greyscale no label etc
Export as jpg
Open in hgt2stl
Export to STL
Open in meshmixer which tidies it up
Save as
Open in Adobe print utility (turn off support) -seems to be the only way I can get a slic3able scaled model
Save as

Card organizer for in the box storage as well as on the table top while you're playing.
The main inputs to the customizer are how big is the card and how tall do you want the caddy (so it'll fit in your game box).  It'll figure out how much slant angle is needed so the cards.  Also, it takes a list of stack heights, so you can easily vary the number of slots as well as have each of them be a custom height.
My original use was for storing my Catan cards.  I have a nice wooden tray for playing that a friend made for me, but I also wanted a way to keep them neatly organized in the box.

My first use of this was to print a card organizer for my Cities and Knights of Catan box. So the default configuration is for those cards combined with the original Catan cards in this order: 5mm stacks of

description.text:
This is a home-made version antifog fan system for your FPV Goggles; a must in the cold days!! This design has been tested on a Fatshark Base SD and Skyzone goggles, but It could work in other models; and remember that you can cut and adapt the eye holes for your goggles. The design it is based on three 3D printed parts, the foam around the goggles and the small fan. Attached you have the three STL files for printing, and a PDF with the foam templates.
There are two versions of the called FanAirGuide, giving you an extra for those big noses ;). The small fan selected is a 12v DC 25x25x10mm that could be easily found online. It has been tested from 6v up to 13v, good to be used with a 2-3s LiPo UPDATES: -If you have problem with your FPV goggle buttons and the FAN holder ( like in the Fatshark Predator), check out Steve's FAN Adaptor for this goggles

0.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes: This design was printed in a FreakyPrinter ( check the website ) using blue ABS 1.75mm, but Black ABS it is recommended to block the light. Slic3r was used to print the parts with the following options:
-0.2mm resolution
-40% infill
-2 walls
-2 bottom layer
-3 bottom layers
-No support, no brim It is a good idea after you finish printing the FacePlate part, and when still hot, you could try to fit it to the goggle so It can get the shape. To fit the faceplate could be at the beginning a bit difficult, you need to find the magic way!

Assembly A hot gun was used to glue the parts, which provides enough support. Using the PDF template you can print it on a paper and cut the foam template. A 15mm black foam was used with good results. To cut the foam you can use scissors, cutter or a hotwire foam cutter ;), check the next picture. There is no instructions on how to connect the fan. The idea will be to make a 5.8GHZ 32-channels custom receiver controlled with an arduino, which It is needed !!!, and used an spare PWM output and one button input to control the fan to add timeout timer and speed options.

title: Pergo's Robo3D (R1 and Plus too) Pressed Bearing Spool Holder

description.text:
Click "remix" or click here
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2155476 Print with 100% infill
Matter control users are reporting issues with "Voids"
This was found to be that users were not rotating the stabilizer bar before print
Select EDIT, then Click Rotate Y (2 times)
OR (for Cura and Matter Control) print with supports. There are SO many spool holders available out there with so many great designs, I learned a lot by using many of them but each didn't quite get there for me personally. After months of "I wish" and "if only..." I designed "Pergo's Spool Holder". I did really like the ideal "Robo3D Top Mount" by "ThorMJ" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:215996) so much that I cut off the ends and included it in my design. He had the right curve and a great quick to connect top mount.. Thanks ThorMJ. My pre-Reqs for my Design:
  • Easy to print
  • Snap together install
  • Everything can be printed except the 22mm OD ball bearings
    http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B010GI2ZJY $7.99 Prime These bearings are very smooth ABEC 3 would be good too.
  • Sturdy
  • Quick Filiment Changes, no nuts or bolts to touch during a filament change
  • Smooth Glide filament path.
  • Stylish and not bulky (after all I have to look at it ALL the time) :)
  • Has to fit a small diameter filament roll. being it's 30mm, Reels with a 32mm hole works.
  • Have to be able to change filament in the middle of a print job if I want to do a color change mid print without moving the carriage.
    • Well this i what I came up with.
    I'm providing the original source 123D files, so please, when you submit something, do the same!
    When printing the 7.9mm rod, you should use glue or your fav bed adhesive method, I think 100% in-fill on the rod is best. Print the rod slow with 100+ fan. Everything else is up to you. (I did 100% on all the parts)
    I've been using this holder for about 3kg of filament without a problem. For sample filaments I use one of the many sample filament spools available and run the 7.9mm rod through the sample reel. Print each part once and print Sides.stl twice.
    Do not print the "Assembled" file, it's just an aid to let you see how everything comes together.
    When snapping the sides together, (you printed 2 of them Sides.stl) I keep the sides that were on the printer bed to the outside.
    Comments please! I will change if you find issues.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

100%

I can go into edit mode and separate the model into two parts, the base curve and the vertical riser.  The software is having issues where the two parts overlap.  The two versions of the slicer program interpreted the model differently.  The version that came with the Robo 3D R1 plus left a very large void at the overlap region.  When I updated the software, the outline of the void was still there but mostly filled in.  When I post pictures, I will try to include one that shows the spot in question.

comments.author: PigSknLava

comments.text:
Thanks for contributing this design. I like it a lot.
However, when I print the sides, there is a void right underneath the post. You have to view the layer map in order to spot it.
I tried to import to Sketchup and fix it but found it too difficult for me. So I just use epoxy to fill up the void after I printed it.
The 7.9mm rod also fits too loosely inside the ABEC bearing and is running the risk of eventually move to one side and fall out. I would recommend increase the diameter by 1mm or so near one side at around 36mm. So that the bearing can jam shut on one side.
comments.author: CJ01

comments.text: With the bearings I bought I had to sand the 7.9 rod because the bearing hole is 8mm It's not meant to be too tight. However please do a Remix on the part to suit your needs. Yes maybe one side larger might be a great idea. Personally I never had a spool slide off the rod. What are the inner dimension of the bearing your using?  if they have a larger inner hole than 8mm then I would see why you think a 7.9mm rod is too small.
comments.author: CJ01

comments.text: Pergo, having the same problem here with the void appearing at the base of the side supports above the curved "foot" section. It's about a 1.5mm H x 44mm L x 6.25mm W rectangle, and causes the upright to snap off the foot when flexed as it is only held on by a thin skirt.  It's as if the upright is translated 1.5mm away from the footer, where it should be flush and fully bonded.

This kitschy jackalope shaped hip flask is inspired by 18th century British gin smugglers who created makeshift flasks from pig bladders. The jackalope is a mythical animal of North American folklore, composed of a jackrabbit with antelope horns. Ironically, a jackrabbit is not a rabbit and the American antelope is not an antelope. One of the ways to catch a jackalope is to entice it with whiskey, the jackalope’s beverage of choice. This stylish hip-flask can be used to lure your area’s local jackalopes, and like with a real jackalope, watch the horns when you drink from this flask.
(Alcohol will dissolve a PLA filament, it is advised that you do not put real whisky or any other type of alcoholic beverage inside the flask.)

The fan base that comes with the Filastruder is made of wood, and the four nuts that are trapped in the wood can be dislodged easily.  This part replaces that wooden part.  
In theory, you can slip four nuts into the slots and then use this part exactly like the wooden part.  In fact, when I printed it, all of the screw holes were just a littlt too small.  I drilled out the four fan mounting screw holes, but left the other four side holes small, and just screwed the side mounting screws directly into the plastic.  
I have included the Sketchup model in case you want to tweak it

It is like a small piano but I use tubes with different thickness instead of strings. So when you push the bottoms, the little hammer will hit the tube and make sounds. As the thickness of the tube changes, the sound will change. Likewise, every part of each key is separated and completely the same. All the part are interchangeable and can be group freely, which means, if you want, you can make a huge key boards. There is NO LIMITATION.

One day I saw the inside of a piano when I was in a music store. At that time, I was working on this project and I thought," That is what I want !" So after I went home, I did some research about how piano works and after I knew the principle, I changed the design to make it fit the printer. That is how I got the idea.

It's a clamp.
Why two? and why the bridge between the two? I had a problem with lifting on my printer, this did the trick for me.
BTW, this was made for the 45L version (56cm x 39cm lid)
Just a key and keychain of the Bates Motel "room 1" from the movie psycho
Cinema 4d

A cover for the exposed electronics on the small USB interface PC board on the 3D Touch printer. It just snaps into place and is held by friction, mostly. It could be modified (.SLDPRT file included) to have real snap fittings, but it stays in place the way it is, so I'm happy with it. Without it, there are bare conductors from the ribbon cable connector on the USB PC board that are exposed. If anything metalic accidentally fell in there it would easily short something to something else. This should keep stray bits of plastic and dust from collecting there also.  
I have revised my original design and uploaded new files, making the cover shorter. The original was unnecessarily tall and I have deleted the files for it (but the photo is still of the tall version).

I used PLA with 0.25mm layers. To install, slide the cover under the front lower horizontal frame bar, between it and the horizontal piece of acrylic plastic below, and to the right of the USB ports, with the notch on the cover facing front and down, then slide the cover to the left and up and over the USB jacks until the notch in the cover fits over the right-most USB jack. Then work the cover down until the small tabs on both sides go into the semi-circular cutouts in the acrylic that provide clearance for the screw heads that hold the USB PC board in place.

title: Glacier Bay Kitchen Sink Button Replacement

description.text: I've got a kitchen sink I bought from Home Depot ( http://tinyurl.com/oyklsha ), and the sink sprayer mode button was a terrible design. After a couple of weeks of use - it broke apart. I was left with a hole in the sprayer head ringed with sharp edges protecting the mode switch. Failing to find the parts to repair, and not wanting to replace the entire spray head to fix one small broken part, I cracked open Fusion 360, and took a stab. This part is more complex than my average design, and I needed to print it with support. But imagine my surprise when at first attempt - it worked. The wife hates it, and it's ugly - but it's ugly functional, and I'm cool with that. One day I'll redesign it, or maybe one of you will, and I'll use yours. either way - enjoy.

description.text: I saw this link a few days ago( http://www.instructables.com/id/Robotic-claw-business-card/ ) I was going to make it, but then I remembered me making a paper claw a few weeks ago, so instead of making a copy of someone else's design, I made my own! And also their design had gears, it would be hard to cut it out without a laser cutter, because I don't have one. So I used the mechanism from my claw and put it into this business card, and it works, and I suggest if you are going to make it, use a laser cutter, This was kinda hard to do and I had to use wire instead of the disks in it to move. If anyone would like to test this to make sure that the parts work, go right ahead! I also think it could be 3d printed, if someone would like to modify it and test that out! And ignore the pink post-it note, I had my name printed there and I dont want it to be online.

Lasercut the pdf, if you want it in a different format, comment below.
The circles with the X in them are for aligning the other parts, do not cut that part out. I also made a laid out illustrator file that would help you build it, it is all the layers side by side, you might want to laser cut that file, it might be easier to build. Oh, and you can flattr if you like it :D

Here is a picture relief map, usually called a lithopane: aer_1948.stl.  
Lithopanes are inverse relief maps and the fortran program used to make relief maps, see thing:110173, was easily modified to make lithopanes.  The program takes a grayscale negative in raw format and outputs an openSCAD program.  When the openSCAD program is executed a lithopane is produced.  
The source code and input file are included.  
Makerbot has a lithopane tool that turns any photograph into a lithopane - see thing:74322.  It is an easy to use application.

The lithopane can be printed directly on the build platform.  I used two shells, 100% infill and natural ABS.  
The input file came from adobe photoshop.  Setting the contrast, clipping out the wanted part, converting to grayscale and inverting are all operations easily carried out with the program.  When finished a raw photo file without headers is exported.  
The data file included here can be opened, inverted, and viewed in adobe photoshop.  aer_1948.raw has 220 rows and 200 columns.

I've often admired the smooth stones with inspirational words engraved on the surface. It turns out that it's not that difficult to create a similar look and feel (although not the heft) with a 3D printer. And the contour lines from the printer add a nice effect to the surface of the stone. 
I used a design tool (Fusion 360) that can create organic shapes and 3D text. Here I've included one stone in English and two in Hebrew. Shalom means peace (and is my name in Hebrew). Misheberach is the name of a healing prayer. This last "stone" can easily fit in your hand and holding it could be a source of comfort for someone that is ill.

title: ἰχθύς (ichthys, fish)

description.text:
At it's root, it's simply a fish shape with the Greek word for fish written inside. However, for Christians this has added meaning because it represents perhaps the first creed (statement of faith) of the Christian church. Many of the apostles were fishermen, and ΙΧΘΥΣ stands for:
Ἰησοῦς (Jesus)
χριστός (Christ)
Θεοῦ (God's)
Ὑιός (Son)
Σωτήρ (Savior)
With the attached excel (or PDF) file, I've been printing twelve 2 1/8" x 3 7/16" cards 2-sided on 8 1/2 x 11 card stock telling about what it means.
Designed in Geomagic Design Had to draw the characters individually because no font would have the letters connect to the basic fish shape.

THIS DESIGN IS /FULLY/ PARAMETRIC. You can specify the angle of the bend in the part from 0-90, the radius of the bends, placement of holes, etc, without having to read through into the nasty, nasty code. So if you can think of any other uses for this basic shape, have at it! If you have been following my custom firmware for Thing O Matic and Repraps, you know that it supports hostless printing using an SD reader, keypad, and LCD. http://reprap.org/wiki/Sjfw I designed a minimal mounting bracket for the keypad and LCD so they can be held in the hand, set on the desk next to the printer, or hooked over the front threaded rods. WIP WHY: Haven't actually printed it yet; too big to print on the ToM and the Prusa Z axis is getting replaced before I print again there.

Print, connect keypad and LCD. Good times. I'll provide some detailed instructions with photos that make the plan a little more clear once I've actually printed one. If you are using the SCAD file, you will need copy of my bend script: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11087

description.text: I saw a wood version of this and I thought that it would make a really cool project for a 3D Printer.
Simple Lasercut case for Beaglebone Black by TI.

No fancy backwards compatibility to the old beaglebone or anything. this is just a quick way to get your board wrapped up in something. You'll need 4 M3 screws + Nuts (40mm length works best) or some glue, or both. Add your own layers to make room for capes. If you have 3mm material only, just cut the file attached(i exported in a few formats..) and you're good to go. If you have 4mm material as well, you may replace layers 2&3(see annotated image) with a single 4mm layer.(stupid mini-usb needs that space)
Designed in Autodesk Inventor. See description for a short manual. Should be pretty self-explanatory anyways.

title: U-Keys: Password Reminder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Do you often forget your passwords? Worry no more! With the “U-Keys” you now have your very own handy password reminder for your Apple Mac keyboard. In an age where internet and computers play a huge part of our lives, we’re constantly creating passwords for social media accounts and so on. Having to manage so many passwords can be overwhelming thus we can often forget passwords for our accounts. With “U-Keys” you can easily customize keyboard patterns that corresponds to your passwords. For instance if my password was “apple” then I would leave the keys “a”, “p”, “l” and “e” empty and cover all the rest with the square key pieces provided. At the same time, the “U-Keys” will only show the letters that make up your password but not the actually ordering of the letters to form your password. Of course, it is important to note that people are constantly changing their passwords. “U-Keys” allows it’s users to rearrange the keys to form the new password, making it a versatile and sustainable product. Using “U-Keys” you can easily remember your passwords, securely manage your passwords and change it whenever you want, making “U.Key” the ultimate password reminder.
Instructions: Print out the Keyboard file then print out the keys file (as many as you want).

description.text: This is an improvement on my old yo-yo design, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39356 The main improvement is that this design allows two small panhead screws to be used to hold the yo-yo to the axle; the previous design relied on friction. In this design, the screws sit nicely in their own countersunk hole. A cutout on the outer face of the yo-yo provides room for you to put, say, a 3d printed medallion or other decoration.

The axle is made by cutting a 25mm long piece of 1/4" hardwood dowel.  This will give you a 3mm string gap; you can cut a different length according to preference.  
As with the other yo-yo, you can mess with the print density to determine the weight of the yo yo.  I find that with PLA, around 75% infill gives a density similar to wood.  
Unlike the previous design, this yo-yo can only be assembled butterfly style.

remixed_from.author: csatti
remixed_from.title: Wanhao Duplicator 4 (Makerbot) X axis stepper motor fan holder (with cable channel)

title: FLashForge Creator Pro X Fan + Cable Chain

description.text:
This is based on csatti's original cable chain and fan setup for the WanHao Duplicator. I wanted to put this on mine and quickly found out that it wasn't going to work. It may work just fine for those creator folks, but the pro will be a no go. The  major problem, the stepper for Y motion is set lower than in the creator and the chain keeps the Y axis from homing (bummer).
So, I fired up sketchup and changed it around and presto works great. I then ran into another obstacle. I wanted the wires to be nicely bundled and make it look nice. I had also read that folks were complaining that either their Y stepper bracket was broken or weak so I came up with this contraption. And it works really well. There is a second revised file that inclues a half hole out the other side as well to allow wires to pass freely to the wire loom and down the frame. On mine I didn't put it in and saw that It should be there so I will be uploading both. It wont hurt, its just for looks and  wont make the cable have a slight bend.
This does Not need any supports nor rafts (however if you prefer you can use rafts( I am printing on a piece of 3/16 glass with kapton and hairspray, this is working perfect for me and I have never had 1 failed print since due to adherence. When it cools, it actually pops loose on its own, if it doesn't and is stubborn or I used too much spray, I tap the object with the end of a putty knife and it pops off))
For the Y bracket I suggest printing as is, using whatever layering suits your needs, I used .27 with 3 shells @ 60% infill. At this size 60% seemed to be so close to being 100% anyways due to the compactness of the object you don't waste the filament and you get the strength needed! This is designed for PLA, but you can use with ABS, Nylon, HIPS, PC Whatever you desire, you may have to make a few adjustments on scale to compensate for shrinkage!
I hope you folks like this and make use out of this. I have it on both of my FFCP's and I love it. I will be adding some more to this as time goes by  so keep checking back. I plan on adding a "finger" if you will, that will span from the front of the front right corner towards the back right 1/4 of the way as a support to hold the chain up so it wont sag. Other than that this is working as is and I have been using it for close to a month. 
My one FFCP just had its main board take a dump, so I am down one unit, but as I stated its on both and works great! Not only will it protect the wire, but sure looks a heck of a lot better than tie-wrapped wires forming a loop next to the Y belt where it can rub and potentially rub through and cause a short!!!
Enjoy! Any suggestions and or requests feel free to contact me!
Thanks. If for some reason this doesn't work for you don't be too harsh, I'm still learning designing for 3d printing, and will more than happily try to make something that will work for you!

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

.27 Or whatever blows your whistle

Infill:

60% on Y bracket 10 on everything else is good

title: MKS v1.3/Sainsmart 2-in-1 case for Replacing RigidBot bord/case

description.text:
Replacing the RigidBot original board with the MKS v1.3 or Sainsmart 2-in-1 board. The case will fit on the original place of the Rigidbot case.
The case has been design to be used together with the ByeBye Board that makes the solution more compatible with the original RigidBot board. More about the case can be found at: http://rigidtalk.com/wiki/index.php?title=Replacing_RB_board_with_MKS_1.3_and_ByeBye_board More about the ByeBye board at http://rigidtalk.com/wiki/index.php?title=BYEBYE_Board_-_community_released_cable_breakout_board The design and the use of cabelchannels will swap the place of Extruder One and two. The text on ByeBye Board will not be correct. The mounting holes on the board is not the same. Thats the reason for the slot/ofset mounting holes. Heatbed and thermistor can be installed on the ByeBye board or directly to The MKS/Sainsmart 2in1 board. If the heatbed is connected directly to the MKS/Sinsmart board the stressrelease/firstlink can be joint to a cable-chain to the heatbed. The cablechain used is this:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/291569545608?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&var=590618557514&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT The cablechain for X-gantry can be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1127859 Cables inside the case are "hidden" inside cablecannels. This will increase airflow and make the installation looks nicer. All channels is not used. Some is used for MKS and some for Sainsmart 2-in-1. The lid is still under construction..
The lid mounting is done by distance nuts from the boards to the lid.
The lid has ducted fan mount for 2*25mm / 30mm/40mm fan Version 3:
All files under construction is available at https://github.com/cabbagecreek/RigidBot-MKS-Case
I am redesigning the case and also made a version without ByeBye board.
It will be possible to change position of the case. I mount that fits the 19mm squere pipes makes it possible to mount it anywhere on the RigidBot (or other 19mm squere pipe based 3D printer)
The advantage of having the mount as a separate part makes it possible to make a custom mount that fit other 3D printers The fan is a ducted "add-on" to the lid. The reason for the 50x50x20 radial fan is that it creates a oversized airflow. When redusing the fanspeed or add a tempcontroll makes the fan very silent.
I have tilted the fan about 10deg to use the space between the RB frame and the Heatbed. I straight version vill be made soon. The fan is offset to get more airflow at extruder stepper driver(s). The "piggy-back" case for the Raspberry Pi uses the output airflow from the MKS case for cooling. The airflow for the MKS case is enought for both MKS and RPi.
Power to the RPi is taken from the PSU case ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:531079 )
Only a short USB cable connect the RPi with the MKS board. Easy to remove when the MKS board needs reprogramming.
This RPi case makes it difficult to use the RPi camera. I use a USB camera.
The case is compatible with Raspberry Pi Zero. (Just use other mounting) 2016-04-22 All files are updated
